trans-unit.source: Guide to the Net# Neural Networks Specification Language | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Guide to the Net# Neural Networks Specification Language | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Syntax for the Net# neural networks specification language, together with examples of how to create a custom neural network model in Microsoft Azure ML using Net#
trans-unit.target: Syntax for the Net# neural networks specification language, together with examples of how to create a custom neural network model in Microsoft Azure ML using Net#

trans-unit.source: Net# is a language developed by Microsoft that is used to define neural network architectures for neural network modules in Microsoft Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Net# is a language developed by Microsoft that is used to define neural network architectures for neural network modules in Microsoft Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn:
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn:

trans-unit.source: Basic concepts related to neural networks
trans-unit.target: Basic concepts related to neural networks

trans-unit.source: Neural network requirements and how to define the primary components
trans-unit.target: Neural network requirements and how to define the primary components

trans-unit.source: The syntax and keywords of the Net# specification language
trans-unit.target: The syntax and keywords of the Net# specification language

trans-unit.source: Examples of custom neural networks created using Net#
trans-unit.target: Examples of custom neural networks created using Net#

trans-unit.source: A neural network structure consists of *nodes* that are organized in *layers*, and weighted *connections* (or *edges*) between the nodes.
trans-unit.target: A neural network structure consists of *nodes* that are organized in *layers*, and weighted *connections* (or *edges*) between the nodes.

trans-unit.source: The connections are directional, and each connection has a *source* node and a *destination* node.
trans-unit.target: The connections are directional, and each connection has a *source* node and a *destination* node.

trans-unit.source: Each *trainable layer* (a hidden or an output layer) has one or more *connection bundles*.
trans-unit.target: Each *trainable layer* (a hidden or an output layer) has one or more *connection bundles*.

trans-unit.source: A connection bundle consists of a source layer and a specification of the connections from that source layer.
trans-unit.target: A connection bundle consists of a source layer and a specification of the connections from that source layer.

trans-unit.source: All the connections in a given bundle share the same *source layer* and the same *destination layer*.
trans-unit.target: All the connections in a given bundle share the same *source layer* and the same *destination layer*.

trans-unit.source: In Net#, a connection bundle is considered as belonging to the bundle's destination layer.
trans-unit.target: In Net#, a connection bundle is considered as belonging to the bundle's destination layer.

trans-unit.source: Net# supports various kinds of connection bundles, which lets you customize the way inputs are mapped to hidden layers and mapped to the outputs.
trans-unit.target: Net# supports various kinds of connection bundles, which lets you customize the way inputs are mapped to hidden layers and mapped to the outputs.

trans-unit.source: The default or standard bundle is a full bundle, in which each node in the source layer is connected to every node in the destination layer.
trans-unit.target: The default or standard bundle is a full bundle, in which each node in the source layer is connected to every node in the destination layer.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, Net# supports the following four kinds of advanced connection bundles:
trans-unit.target: Additionally, Net# supports the following four kinds of advanced connection bundles:

trans-unit.source: Filtered bundles.
trans-unit.target: Filtered bundles.

trans-unit.source: The user can define a predicate by using the locations of the source layer node and the destination layer node.
trans-unit.target: The user can define a predicate by using the locations of the source layer node and the destination layer node.

trans-unit.source: Nodes are connected whenever the predicate is True.
trans-unit.target: Nodes are connected whenever the predicate is True.

trans-unit.source: Convolutional bundles.
trans-unit.target: Convolutional bundles.

trans-unit.source: The user can define small neighborhoods of nodes in the source layer.
trans-unit.target: The user can define small neighborhoods of nodes in the source layer.

trans-unit.source: Each node in the destination layer is connected to one neighborhood of nodes in the source layer.
trans-unit.target: Each node in the destination layer is connected to one neighborhood of nodes in the source layer.

trans-unit.source: Pooling bundles and Response normalization bundles.
trans-unit.target: Pooling bundles and Response normalization bundles.

trans-unit.source: These are similar to convolutional bundles in that the user defines small neighborhoods of nodes in the source layer.
trans-unit.target: These are similar to convolutional bundles in that the user defines small neighborhoods of nodes in the source layer.

trans-unit.source: The difference is that the weights of the edges in these bundles are not trainable.
trans-unit.target: The difference is that the weights of the edges in these bundles are not trainable.

trans-unit.source: Instead, a predefined function is applied to the source node values to determine the destination node value.
trans-unit.target: Instead, a predefined function is applied to the source node values to determine the destination node value.

trans-unit.source: Using Net# to define the structure of a neural network makes it possible to define complex structures such as deep neural networks or convolutions of arbitrary dimensions, which are known to improve learning on data such as image, audio, or video.
trans-unit.target: Using Net# to define the structure of a neural network makes it possible to define complex structures such as deep neural networks or convolutions of arbitrary dimensions, which are known to improve learning on data such as image, audio, or video.

trans-unit.source: The architecture of neural network models that you create in Azure Machine Learning can be extensively customized by using Net#.
trans-unit.target: The architecture of neural network models that you create in Azure Machine Learning can be extensively customized by using Net#.

trans-unit.source: You can:
trans-unit.target: You can:

trans-unit.source: Create hidden layers and control the number of nodes in each layer.
trans-unit.target: Create hidden layers and control the number of nodes in each layer.

trans-unit.source: Specify how layers are to be connected to each other.
trans-unit.target: Specify how layers are to be connected to each other.

trans-unit.source: Define special connectivity structures, such as convolutions and weight sharing bundles.
trans-unit.target: Define special connectivity structures, such as convolutions and weight sharing bundles.

trans-unit.source: Specify different activation functions.
trans-unit.target: Specify different activation functions.

trans-unit.source: For details of the specification language syntax, see Structure Specification.
trans-unit.target: For details of the specification language syntax, see Structure Specification.

trans-unit.source: For examples of defining neural networks for some common machine learning tasks, from simplex to complex, see Examples.
trans-unit.target: For examples of defining neural networks for some common machine learning tasks, from simplex to complex, see Examples.

trans-unit.source: There must be exactly one output layer, at least one input layer, and zero or more hidden layers.
trans-unit.target: There must be exactly one output layer, at least one input layer, and zero or more hidden layers.

trans-unit.source: Each layer has a fixed number of nodes, conceptually arranged in a rectangular array of arbitrary dimensions.
trans-unit.target: Each layer has a fixed number of nodes, conceptually arranged in a rectangular array of arbitrary dimensions.

trans-unit.source: Input layers have no associated trained parameters and represent the point where instance data enters the network.
trans-unit.target: Input layers have no associated trained parameters and represent the point where instance data enters the network.

trans-unit.source: Trainable layers (the hidden and output layers) have associated trained parameters, known as weights and biases.
trans-unit.target: Trainable layers (the hidden and output layers) have associated trained parameters, known as weights and biases.

trans-unit.source: The source and destination nodes must be in separate layers.
trans-unit.target: The source and destination nodes must be in separate layers.

trans-unit.source: Connections must be acyclic; in other words, there cannot be a chain of connections leading back to the initial source node.
trans-unit.target: Connections must be acyclic; in other words, there cannot be a chain of connections leading back to the initial source node.

trans-unit.source: The output layer cannot be a source layer of a connection bundle.
trans-unit.target: The output layer cannot be a source layer of a connection bundle.

trans-unit.source: A neural network structure specification is composed of three sections: the constant declaration, the layer declaration, the connection declaration.
trans-unit.target: A neural network structure specification is composed of three sections: the constant declaration, the layer declaration, the connection declaration.

trans-unit.source: There is also an optional share declaration section.
trans-unit.target: There is also an optional share declaration section.

trans-unit.source: The sections can be specified in any order.
trans-unit.target: The sections can be specified in any order.

trans-unit.source: A constant declaration is optional.
trans-unit.target: A constant declaration is optional.

trans-unit.source: It provides a means to define values used elsewhere in the neural network definition.
trans-unit.target: It provides a means to define values used elsewhere in the neural network definition.

trans-unit.source: The declaration statement consists of an identifier followed by an equal sign and a value expression.
trans-unit.target: The declaration statement consists of an identifier followed by an equal sign and a value expression.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following statement defines a constant x:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following statement defines a constant x:

trans-unit.source: To define two or more constants simultaneously, enclose the identifier names and values in braces, and separate them by using semicolons.
trans-unit.target: To define two or more constants simultaneously, enclose the identifier names and values in braces, and separate them by using semicolons.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The right-hand side of each assignment expression can be an integer, a real number, a Boolean value (True or False), or a mathematical expression.
trans-unit.target: The right-hand side of each assignment expression can be an integer, a real number, a Boolean value (True or False), or a mathematical expression.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The layer declaration is required.
trans-unit.target: The layer declaration is required.

trans-unit.source: It defines the size and source of the layer, including its connection bundles and attributes.
trans-unit.target: It defines the size and source of the layer, including its connection bundles and attributes.

trans-unit.source: The declaration statement starts with the name of the layer (input, hidden, or output), followed by the dimensions of the layer (a tuple of positive integers).
trans-unit.target: The declaration statement starts with the name of the layer (input, hidden, or output), followed by the dimensions of the layer (a tuple of positive integers).

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The product of the dimensions is the number of nodes in the layer.
trans-unit.target: The product of the dimensions is the number of nodes in the layer.

trans-unit.source: In this example, there are two dimensions [5,20], which means there are 100 nodes in the layer.
trans-unit.target: In this example, there are two dimensions [5,20], which means there are 100 nodes in the layer.

trans-unit.source: The layers can be declared in any order, with one exception: If more than one input layer is defined, the order in which they are declared must match the order of features in the input data.
trans-unit.target: The layers can be declared in any order, with one exception: If more than one input layer is defined, the order in which they are declared must match the order of features in the input data.

trans-unit.source: A layer declaration for a trainable layer (the hidden or output layers) can optionally include the output function (also called an activation function), which defaults to sigmoid.
trans-unit.target: A layer declaration for a trainable layer (the hidden or output layers) can optionally include the output function (also called an activation function), which defaults to sigmoid.

trans-unit.source: The following output functions are supported:
trans-unit.target: The following output functions are supported:

trans-unit.source: sigmoid
trans-unit.target: sigmoid

trans-unit.source: linear
trans-unit.target: linear

trans-unit.source: softmax
trans-unit.target: softmax

trans-unit.source: rlinear
trans-unit.target: rlinear

trans-unit.source: square
trans-unit.target: square

trans-unit.source: sqrt
trans-unit.target: sqrt

trans-unit.source: srlinear
trans-unit.target: srlinear

trans-unit.source: abs
trans-unit.target: abs

trans-unit.source: tanh
trans-unit.target: tanh

trans-unit.source: brlinear
trans-unit.target: brlinear

trans-unit.source: For example, the following declaration uses the softmax function:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following declaration uses the softmax function:

trans-unit.source: Immediately after defining the trainable layer, you must declare connections among the layers you have defined.
trans-unit.target: Immediately after defining the trainable layer, you must declare connections among the layers you have defined.

trans-unit.source: The connection bundle declaration starts with the keyword from, followed by the name of the bundle's source layer and the kind of connection bundle to create.
trans-unit.target: The connection bundle declaration starts with the keyword from, followed by the name of the bundle's source layer and the kind of connection bundle to create.

trans-unit.source: Currently, five kinds of connection bundles are supported:
trans-unit.target: Currently, five kinds of connection bundles are supported:

trans-unit.source: Full bundles, indicated by the keyword all
trans-unit.target: Full bundles, indicated by the keyword all

trans-unit.source: Filtered bundles, indicated by the keyword where, followed by a predicate expression
trans-unit.target: Filtered bundles, indicated by the keyword where, followed by a predicate expression

trans-unit.source: Convolutional bundles, indicated by the keyword convolve, followed by the convolution attributes
trans-unit.target: Convolutional bundles, indicated by the keyword convolve, followed by the convolution attributes

trans-unit.source: Pooling bundles, indicated by the keywords max pool or mean pool
trans-unit.target: Pooling bundles, indicated by the keywords max pool or mean pool

trans-unit.source: Response normalization bundles, indicated by the keyword response norm
trans-unit.target: Response normalization bundles, indicated by the keyword response norm

trans-unit.source: A full connection bundle includes a connection from each node in the source layer to each node in the destination layer.
trans-unit.target: A full connection bundle includes a connection from each node in the source layer to each node in the destination layer.

trans-unit.source: This is the default network connection type.
trans-unit.target: This is the default network connection type.

trans-unit.source: A filtered connection bundle specification includes a predicate, expressed syntactically, much like a C# lambda expression.
trans-unit.target: A filtered connection bundle specification includes a predicate, expressed syntactically, much like a C# lambda expression.

trans-unit.source: The following example defines two filtered bundles:
trans-unit.target: The following example defines two filtered bundles:

trans-unit.source: In the predicate for ByRow, s is a parameter representing an index into the rectangular array of nodes of the input layer, Pixels, and d is a parameter representing an index into the array of nodes of the hidden layer, ByRow. The type of both s and d is a tuple of integers of length two. Conceptually, s ranges over all pairs of integers with 0 <= s[0] < 10 and 0 <= s[1] < 20, and d ranges over all pairs of integers, with 0 <= d[0] < 10 and 0 <= d[1] < 12.
trans-unit.target: In the predicate for ByRow, s is a parameter representing an index into the rectangular array of nodes of the input layer, Pixels, and d is a parameter representing an index into the array of nodes of the hidden layer, ByRow. The type of both s and d is a tuple of integers of length two. Conceptually, s ranges over all pairs of integers with 0 <= s[0] < 10 and 0 <= s[1] < 20, and d ranges over all pairs of integers, with 0 <= d[0] < 10 and 0 <= d[1] < 12.

trans-unit.source: On the right-hand side of the predicate expression, there is a condition.
trans-unit.target: On the right-hand side of the predicate expression, there is a condition.

trans-unit.source: In this example, for every value of s and d such that the condition is True, there is an edge from the source layer node to the destination layer node.
trans-unit.target: In this example, for every value of s and d such that the condition is True, there is an edge from the source layer node to the destination layer node.

trans-unit.source: Thus, this filter expression indicates that the bundle includes a connection from the node defined by s to the node defined by d in all cases where s[0] is equal to d[0].
trans-unit.target: Thus, this filter expression indicates that the bundle includes a connection from the node defined by s to the node defined by d in all cases where s[0] is equal to d[0].

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can specify a set of weights for a filtered bundle.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can specify a set of weights for a filtered bundle.

trans-unit.source: The value for the Weights attribute must be a tuple of floating point values with a length that matches the number of connections defined by the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The value for the Weights attribute must be a tuple of floating point values with a length that matches the number of connections defined by the bundle.

trans-unit.source: By default, weights are randomly generated.
trans-unit.target: By default, weights are randomly generated.

trans-unit.source: Weight values are grouped by the destination node index.
trans-unit.target: Weight values are grouped by the destination node index.

trans-unit.source: That is, if the first destination node is connected to K source nodes, the first K elements of the Weights tuple are the weights for the first destination node, in source index order.
trans-unit.target: That is, if the first destination node is connected to K source nodes, the first K elements of the Weights tuple are the weights for the first destination node, in source index order.

trans-unit.source: The same applies for the remaining destination nodes.
trans-unit.target: The same applies for the remaining destination nodes.

trans-unit.source: When the training data has a homogeneous structure, convolutional connections are commonly used to learn high-level features of the data.
trans-unit.target: When the training data has a homogeneous structure, convolutional connections are commonly used to learn high-level features of the data.

trans-unit.source: For example, in image, audio, or video data, spatial or temporal dimensionality can be fairly uniform.
trans-unit.target: For example, in image, audio, or video data, spatial or temporal dimensionality can be fairly uniform.

trans-unit.source: Convolutional bundles employ rectangular kernels that are slid through the dimensions.
trans-unit.target: Convolutional bundles employ rectangular kernels that are slid through the dimensions.

trans-unit.source: Essentially, each kernel defines a set of weights applied in local neighborhoods, referred to as kernel applications.
trans-unit.target: Essentially, each kernel defines a set of weights applied in local neighborhoods, referred to as kernel applications.

trans-unit.source: Each kernel application corresponds to a node in the source layer, which is referred to as the central node.
trans-unit.target: Each kernel application corresponds to a node in the source layer, which is referred to as the central node.

trans-unit.source: The weights of a kernel are shared among many connections.
trans-unit.target: The weights of a kernel are shared among many connections.

trans-unit.source: In a convolutional bundle, each kernel is rectangular and all kernel applications are the same size.
trans-unit.target: In a convolutional bundle, each kernel is rectangular and all kernel applications are the same size.

trans-unit.source: Convolutional bundles support the following attributes:
trans-unit.target: Convolutional bundles support the following attributes:

trans-unit.source: InputShape defines the dimensionality of the source layer for the purposes of this convolutional bundle.
trans-unit.target: InputShape defines the dimensionality of the source layer for the purposes of this convolutional bundle.

trans-unit.source: The value must be a tuple of positive integers.
trans-unit.target: The value must be a tuple of positive integers.

trans-unit.source: The product of the integers must equal the number of nodes in the source layer, but otherwise, it does not need to match the dimensionality declared for the source layer.
trans-unit.target: The product of the integers must equal the number of nodes in the source layer, but otherwise, it does not need to match the dimensionality declared for the source layer.

trans-unit.source: The length of this tuple becomes the arity value for the convolutional bundle.
trans-unit.target: The length of this tuple becomes the arity value for the convolutional bundle.

trans-unit.source: (Typically arity refers to the number of arguments or operands that a function can take.)
trans-unit.target: (Typically arity refers to the number of arguments or operands that a function can take.)

trans-unit.source: To define the shape and locations of the kernels, use the attributes KernelShape, Stride, Padding, LowerPad, and UpperPad:
trans-unit.target: To define the shape and locations of the kernels, use the attributes KernelShape, Stride, Padding, LowerPad, and UpperPad:

trans-unit.source: KernelShape: (required) Defines the dimensionality of each kernel for the convolutional bundle.
trans-unit.target: KernelShape: (required) Defines the dimensionality of each kernel for the convolutional bundle.

trans-unit.source: The value must be a tuple of positive integers with a length that equals the arity of the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The value must be a tuple of positive integers with a length that equals the arity of the bundle.

trans-unit.source: Each component of this tuple must be no greater than the corresponding component of InputShape.
trans-unit.target: Each component of this tuple must be no greater than the corresponding component of InputShape.

trans-unit.source: Stride: (optional) Defines the sliding step sizes of the convolution (one step size for each dimension), that is the distance between the central nodes.
trans-unit.target: Stride: (optional) Defines the sliding step sizes of the convolution (one step size for each dimension), that is the distance between the central nodes.

trans-unit.source: The value must be a tuple of positive integers with a length that is the arity of the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The value must be a tuple of positive integers with a length that is the arity of the bundle.

trans-unit.source: Each component of this tuple must be no greater than the corresponding component of KernelShape.
trans-unit.target: Each component of this tuple must be no greater than the corresponding component of KernelShape.

trans-unit.source: The default value is a tuple with all components equal to one.
trans-unit.target: The default value is a tuple with all components equal to one.

trans-unit.source: Sharing: (optional) Defines the weight sharing for each dimension of the convolution.
trans-unit.target: Sharing: (optional) Defines the weight sharing for each dimension of the convolution.

trans-unit.source: The value can be a single Boolean value or a tuple of Boolean values with a length that is the arity of the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The value can be a single Boolean value or a tuple of Boolean values with a length that is the arity of the bundle.

trans-unit.source: A single Boolean value is extended to be a tuple of the correct length with all components equal to the specified value.
trans-unit.target: A single Boolean value is extended to be a tuple of the correct length with all components equal to the specified value.

trans-unit.source: The default value is a tuple that consists of all True values.
trans-unit.target: The default value is a tuple that consists of all True values.

trans-unit.source: MapCount: (optional) Defines the number of feature maps for the convolutional bundle.
trans-unit.target: MapCount: (optional) Defines the number of feature maps for the convolutional bundle.

trans-unit.source: The value can be a single positive integer or a tuple of positive integers with a length that is the arity of the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The value can be a single positive integer or a tuple of positive integers with a length that is the arity of the bundle.

trans-unit.source: A single integer value is extended to be a tuple of the correct length with the first components equal to the specified value and all the remaining components equal to one.
trans-unit.target: A single integer value is extended to be a tuple of the correct length with the first components equal to the specified value and all the remaining components equal to one.

trans-unit.source: The default value is one.
trans-unit.target: The default value is one.

trans-unit.source: The total number of feature maps is the product of the components of the tuple.
trans-unit.target: The total number of feature maps is the product of the components of the tuple.

trans-unit.source: The factoring of this total number across the components determines how the feature map values are grouped in the destination nodes.
trans-unit.target: The factoring of this total number across the components determines how the feature map values are grouped in the destination nodes.

trans-unit.source: Weights: (optional) Defines the initial weights for the bundle.
trans-unit.target: Weights: (optional) Defines the initial weights for the bundle.

trans-unit.source: The value must be a tuple of floating point values with a length that is the number of kernels times the number of weights per kernel, as defined later in this article.
trans-unit.target: The value must be a tuple of floating point values with a length that is the number of kernels times the number of weights per kernel, as defined later in this article.

trans-unit.source: The default weights are randomly generated.
trans-unit.target: The default weights are randomly generated.

trans-unit.source: There are two sets of properties that control padding, which are mutually exclusive:
trans-unit.target: There are two sets of properties that control padding, which are mutually exclusive:

trans-unit.source: Padding: (optional) Determines whether the input should be padded by using a default padding scheme.
trans-unit.target: Padding: (optional) Determines whether the input should be padded by using a default padding scheme.

trans-unit.source: The value can be a single Boolean value, or it can be a tuple of Boolean values with a length that is the arity of the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The value can be a single Boolean value, or it can be a tuple of Boolean values with a length that is the arity of the bundle.

trans-unit.source: A single Boolean value is extended to be a tuple of the correct length with all components equal to the specified value.
trans-unit.target: A single Boolean value is extended to be a tuple of the correct length with all components equal to the specified value.

trans-unit.source: If the value for a dimension is True, the source is logically padded in that dimension with zero-valued cells to support additional kernel applications, such that the central nodes of the first and last kernels in that dimension are the first and last nodes in that dimension in the source layer.
trans-unit.target: If the value for a dimension is True, the source is logically padded in that dimension with zero-valued cells to support additional kernel applications, such that the central nodes of the first and last kernels in that dimension are the first and last nodes in that dimension in the source layer.

trans-unit.source: Thus, the number of "dummy" nodes in each dimension is determined automatically, to fit exactly (InputShape[d] - 1) / Stride[d] + 1 kernels into the padded source layer.
trans-unit.target: Thus, the number of "dummy" nodes in each dimension is determined automatically, to fit exactly (InputShape[d] - 1) / Stride[d] + 1 kernels into the padded source layer.

trans-unit.source: If the value for a dimension is False, the kernels are defined so that the number of nodes on each side that are left out is the same (up to a difference of 1).
trans-unit.target: If the value for a dimension is False, the kernels are defined so that the number of nodes on each side that are left out is the same (up to a difference of 1).

trans-unit.source: The default value of this attribute is a tuple with all components equal to False.
trans-unit.target: The default value of this attribute is a tuple with all components equal to False.

trans-unit.source: UpperPad and LowerPad: (optional) Provide greater control over the amount of padding to use.
trans-unit.target: UpperPad and LowerPad: (optional) Provide greater control over the amount of padding to use.

trans-unit.source: Important: These attributes can be defined if and only if the Padding property above is *not* defined.
trans-unit.target: Important: These attributes can be defined if and only if the Padding property above is *not* defined.

trans-unit.source: The values should be integer-valued tuples with lengths that are the arity of the bundle.
trans-unit.target: The values should be integer-valued tuples with lengths that are the arity of the bundle.

trans-unit.source: When these attributes are specified, "dummy" nodes are added to the lower and upper ends of each dimension of the input layer.
trans-unit.target: When these attributes are specified, "dummy" nodes are added to the lower and upper ends of each dimension of the input layer.

trans-unit.source: The number of nodes added to the lower and upper ends in each dimension is determined by LowerPad[i] and UpperPad[i] respectively.
trans-unit.target: The number of nodes added to the lower and upper ends in each dimension is determined by LowerPad[i] and UpperPad[i] respectively.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that kernels correspond only to "real" nodes and not to "dummy" nodes, the following conditions must be met:
trans-unit.target: To ensure that kernels correspond only to "real" nodes and not to "dummy" nodes, the following conditions must be met:

trans-unit.source: Each component of LowerPad must be strictly less than KernelShape[d]/2.
trans-unit.target: Each component of LowerPad must be strictly less than KernelShape[d]/2.

trans-unit.source: Each component of UpperPad must be no greater than KernelShape[d]/2.
trans-unit.target: Each component of UpperPad must be no greater than KernelShape[d]/2.

trans-unit.source: The default value of these attributes is a tuple with all components equal to 0.
trans-unit.target: The default value of these attributes is a tuple with all components equal to 0.

trans-unit.source: The setting Padding = true allows as much padding as is needed to keep the "center" of the kernel inside the "real" input.
trans-unit.target: The setting Padding = true allows as much padding as is needed to keep the "center" of the kernel inside the "real" input.

trans-unit.source: This changes the math a bit for computing the output size.
trans-unit.target: This changes the math a bit for computing the output size.

trans-unit.source: Generally, the output size D is computed as D = (I - K) / S + 1, where I is the input size, K is the kernel size, S is the stride, and / is integer division (round toward zero).
trans-unit.target: Generally, the output size D is computed as D = (I - K) / S + 1, where I is the input size, K is the kernel size, S is the stride, and / is integer division (round toward zero).

trans-unit.source: If you set UpperPad = [1, 1], the input size I is effectively 29, and thus D = (29 - 5) / 2 + 1 = 13.
trans-unit.target: If you set UpperPad = [1, 1], the input size I is effectively 29, and thus D = (29 - 5) / 2 + 1 = 13.

trans-unit.source: However, when Padding = true, essentially I gets bumped up by K - 1; hence D = ((28 + 4) - 5) / 2 + 1 = 27 / 2 + 1 = 13 + 1 = 14.
trans-unit.target: However, when Padding = true, essentially I gets bumped up by K - 1; hence D = ((28 + 4) - 5) / 2 + 1 = 27 / 2 + 1 = 13 + 1 = 14.

trans-unit.source: By specifying values for UpperPad and LowerPad you get much more control over the padding than if you just set Padding = true.
trans-unit.target: By specifying values for UpperPad and LowerPad you get much more control over the padding than if you just set Padding = true.

trans-unit.source: For more information about convolutional networks and their applications, see these articles:
trans-unit.target: For more information about convolutional networks and their applications, see these articles:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>http://deeplearning.net/tutorial/lenet.html </linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>http://deeplearning.net/tutorial/lenet.html </linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>http://research.microsoft.com/pubs/68920/icdar03.pdf</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>http://research.microsoft.com/pubs/68920/icdar03.pdf</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: [http://people.csail.mit.edu/jvb/papers/cnntutorial.pdf](http://people.csail.mit.edu/jvb/papers/cnntutorial.pdf)
trans-unit.target: [http://people.csail.mit.edu/jvb/papers/cnntutorial.pdf](http://people.csail.mit.edu/jvb/papers/cnntutorial.pdf)

trans-unit.source: A pooling bundle applies geometry similar to convolutional connectivity, but it uses predefined functions to source node values to derive the destination node value.
trans-unit.target: A pooling bundle applies geometry similar to convolutional connectivity, but it uses predefined functions to source node values to derive the destination node value.

trans-unit.source: Hence, pooling bundles have no trainable state (weights or biases).
trans-unit.target: Hence, pooling bundles have no trainable state (weights or biases).

trans-unit.source: Pooling bundles support all the convolutional attributes except Sharing, MapCount, and Weights.
trans-unit.target: Pooling bundles support all the convolutional attributes except Sharing, MapCount, and Weights.

trans-unit.source: Typically, the kernels summarized by adjacent pooling units do not overlap.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the kernels summarized by adjacent pooling units do not overlap.

trans-unit.source: If Stride[d] is equal to KernelShape[d] in each dimension, the layer obtained is the traditional local pooling layer, which is commonly employed in convolutional neural networks.
trans-unit.target: If Stride[d] is equal to KernelShape[d] in each dimension, the layer obtained is the traditional local pooling layer, which is commonly employed in convolutional neural networks.

trans-unit.source: Each destination node computes the maximum or the mean of the activities of its kernel in the source layer.
trans-unit.target: Each destination node computes the maximum or the mean of the activities of its kernel in the source layer.

trans-unit.source: The following example illustrates a pooling bundle:
trans-unit.target: The following example illustrates a pooling bundle:

trans-unit.source: The arity of the bundle is 3 (the length of the tuples InputShape, KernelShape, and Stride).
trans-unit.target: The arity of the bundle is 3 (the length of the tuples InputShape, KernelShape, and Stride).

trans-unit.source: The number of nodes in the source layer is 5 * 24 * 24 = 2880.
trans-unit.target: The number of nodes in the source layer is 5 * 24 * 24 = 2880.

trans-unit.source: This is a traditional local pooling layer because KernelShape and Stride are equal.
trans-unit.target: This is a traditional local pooling layer because KernelShape and Stride are equal.

trans-unit.source: The number of nodes in the destination layer is 5 * 12 * 12 = 1440.
trans-unit.target: The number of nodes in the destination layer is 5 * 12 * 12 = 1440.

trans-unit.source: For more information about pooling layers, see these articles:
trans-unit.target: For more information about pooling layers, see these articles:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/absps/imagenet.pdf</linkText><title></title> (Section 3.4)
trans-unit.target: <linkText>http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/absps/imagenet.pdf</linkText><title></title> (Section 3.4)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>http://cs.nyu.edu/~koray/publis/lecun-iscas-10.pdf</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>http://cs.nyu.edu/~koray/publis/lecun-iscas-10.pdf</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>http://cs.nyu.edu/~koray/publis/jarrett-iccv-09.pdf</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>http://cs.nyu.edu/~koray/publis/jarrett-iccv-09.pdf</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Response normalization is a local normalization scheme that was first introduced by Geoffrey Hinton, et al, in a paper titled ImageNet Classiﬁcation with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (see section 3.3).
trans-unit.target: Response normalization is a local normalization scheme that was first introduced by Geoffrey Hinton, et al, in a paper titled ImageNet Classiﬁcation with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (see section 3.3).

trans-unit.source: Response normalization is used to aid generalization in neural nets.
trans-unit.target: Response normalization is used to aid generalization in neural nets.

trans-unit.source: When one neuron is firing at a very high activation level, a local response normalization layer suppresses the activation level of the surrounding neurons.
trans-unit.target: When one neuron is firing at a very high activation level, a local response normalization layer suppresses the activation level of the surrounding neurons.

trans-unit.source: This is done by using three parameters (*α*, *β*, and *k*) and a convolutional structure (or neighborhood shape).
trans-unit.target: This is done by using three parameters (*α*, *β*, and *k*) and a convolutional structure (or neighborhood shape).

trans-unit.source: Every neuron in the destination layer *y* corresponds to a neuron *x* in the source layer.
trans-unit.target: Every neuron in the destination layer *y* corresponds to a neuron *x* in the source layer.

trans-unit.source: The activation level of *y* is given by the following formula, where *f* is the activation level of a neuron, and *Nx* is the kernel (or the set that contains the neurons in the neighborhood of *x*), as defined by the following convolutional structure:
trans-unit.target: The activation level of *y* is given by the following formula, where *f* is the activation level of a neuron, and *Nx* is the kernel (or the set that contains the neurons in the neighborhood of *x*), as defined by the following convolutional structure:

trans-unit.source: Response normalization bundles support all the convolutional attributes except Sharing, MapCount, and Weights.
trans-unit.target: Response normalization bundles support all the convolutional attributes except Sharing, MapCount, and Weights.

trans-unit.source: If the kernel contains neurons in the same map as *x*, the normalization scheme is referred to as same map normalization.
trans-unit.target: If the kernel contains neurons in the same map as *x*, the normalization scheme is referred to as same map normalization.

trans-unit.source: To define same map normalization, the first coordinate in InputShape must have the value 1.
trans-unit.target: To define same map normalization, the first coordinate in InputShape must have the value 1.

trans-unit.source: If the kernel contains neurons in the same spatial position as *x*, but the neurons are in other maps, the normalization scheme is called across maps normalization.
trans-unit.target: If the kernel contains neurons in the same spatial position as *x*, but the neurons are in other maps, the normalization scheme is called across maps normalization.

trans-unit.source: This type of response normalization implements a form of lateral inhibition inspired by the type found in real neurons, creating competition for big activation levels amongst neuron outputs computed on different maps.
trans-unit.target: This type of response normalization implements a form of lateral inhibition inspired by the type found in real neurons, creating competition for big activation levels amongst neuron outputs computed on different maps.

trans-unit.source: To define across maps normalization, the first coordinate must be an integer greater than one and no greater than the number of maps, and the rest of the coordinates must have the value 1.
trans-unit.target: To define across maps normalization, the first coordinate must be an integer greater than one and no greater than the number of maps, and the rest of the coordinates must have the value 1.

trans-unit.source: Because response normalization bundles apply a predefined function to source node values to determine the destination node value, they have no trainable state (weights or biases).
trans-unit.target: Because response normalization bundles apply a predefined function to source node values to determine the destination node value, they have no trainable state (weights or biases).

trans-unit.source: Alert: The nodes in the destination layer correspond to neurons that are the central nodes of the kernels.
trans-unit.target: Alert: The nodes in the destination layer correspond to neurons that are the central nodes of the kernels.

trans-unit.source: For example, if KernelShape[d] is odd, then KernelShape[d]/2 corresponds to the central kernel node.
trans-unit.target: For example, if KernelShape[d] is odd, then KernelShape[d]/2 corresponds to the central kernel node.

trans-unit.source: If KernelShape[d] is even, the central node is at KernelShape[d]/2 - 1.
trans-unit.target: If KernelShape[d] is even, the central node is at KernelShape[d]/2 - 1.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, if Padding[d] is False, the first and the last KernelShape[d]/2 nodes do not have corresponding nodes in the destination layer.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, if Padding[d] is False, the first and the last KernelShape[d]/2 nodes do not have corresponding nodes in the destination layer.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this situation, define Padding as [true, true, …, true].
trans-unit.target: To avoid this situation, define Padding as [true, true, …, true].

trans-unit.source: In addition to the four attributes described earlier, response normalization bundles also support the following attributes:
trans-unit.target: In addition to the four attributes described earlier, response normalization bundles also support the following attributes:

trans-unit.source: Alpha: (required) Specifies a floating-point value that corresponds to *α* in the previous formula.
trans-unit.target: Alpha: (required) Specifies a floating-point value that corresponds to *α* in the previous formula.

trans-unit.source: Beta: (required) Specifies a floating-point value that corresponds to *β* in the previous formula.
trans-unit.target: Beta: (required) Specifies a floating-point value that corresponds to *β* in the previous formula.

trans-unit.source: Offset: (optional) Specifies a floating-point value that corresponds to *k* in the previous formula.
trans-unit.target: Offset: (optional) Specifies a floating-point value that corresponds to *k* in the previous formula.

trans-unit.source: It defaults to 1.
trans-unit.target: It defaults to 1.

trans-unit.source: The following example defines a response normalization bundle using these attributes:
trans-unit.target: The following example defines a response normalization bundle using these attributes:

trans-unit.source: The source layer includes five maps, each with aof dimension of 12x12, totaling in 1440 nodes.
trans-unit.target: The source layer includes five maps, each with aof dimension of 12x12, totaling in 1440 nodes.

trans-unit.source: The value of KernelShape indicates that this is a same map normalization layer, where the neighborhood is a 3x3 rectangle.
trans-unit.target: The value of KernelShape indicates that this is a same map normalization layer, where the neighborhood is a 3x3 rectangle.

trans-unit.source: The default value of Padding is False, thus the destination layer has only 10 nodes in each dimension.
trans-unit.target: The default value of Padding is False, thus the destination layer has only 10 nodes in each dimension.

trans-unit.source: To include one node in the destination layer that corresponds to every node in the source layer, add Padding = [true, true, true]; and change the size of RN1 to [5, 12, 12].
trans-unit.target: To include one node in the destination layer that corresponds to every node in the source layer, add Padding = [true, true, true]; and change the size of RN1 to [5, 12, 12].

trans-unit.source: Net# optionally supports defining multiple bundles with shared weights.
trans-unit.target: Net# optionally supports defining multiple bundles with shared weights.

trans-unit.source: The weights of any two bundles can be shared if their structures are the same.
trans-unit.target: The weights of any two bundles can be shared if their structures are the same.

trans-unit.source: The following syntax defines bundles with shared weights:
trans-unit.target: The following syntax defines bundles with shared weights:

trans-unit.source: For example, the following share-declaration specifies the layer names, indicating that both weights and biases should be shared:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following share-declaration specifies the layer names, indicating that both weights and biases should be shared:

trans-unit.source: The input features are partitioned into two equal sized input layers.
trans-unit.target: The input features are partitioned into two equal sized input layers.

trans-unit.source: The hidden layers then compute higher level features on the two input layers.
trans-unit.target: The hidden layers then compute higher level features on the two input layers.

trans-unit.source: The share-declaration specifies that H1 and H2 must be computed in the same way from their respective inputs.
trans-unit.target: The share-declaration specifies that H1 and H2 must be computed in the same way from their respective inputs.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, this could be specified with two separate share-declarations as follows:
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, this could be specified with two separate share-declarations as follows:

trans-unit.source: You can use the short form only when the layers contain a single bundle.
trans-unit.target: You can use the short form only when the layers contain a single bundle.

trans-unit.source: In general, sharing is possible only when the relevant structure is identical, meaning that they have the same size, same convolutional geometry, and so forth.
trans-unit.target: In general, sharing is possible only when the relevant structure is identical, meaning that they have the same size, same convolutional geometry, and so forth.

trans-unit.source: This section provides some examples of how you can use Net# to add hidden layers, define the way that hidden layers interact with other layers, and build convolutional networks.
trans-unit.target: This section provides some examples of how you can use Net# to add hidden layers, define the way that hidden layers interact with other layers, and build convolutional networks.

trans-unit.source: This simple example demonstrates how to create a neural network model that has a single hidden layer.
trans-unit.target: This simple example demonstrates how to create a neural network model that has a single hidden layer.

trans-unit.source: The example illustrates some basic commands as follows:
trans-unit.target: The example illustrates some basic commands as follows:

trans-unit.source: The first line defines the input layer (named Data), which has 100 nodes, and each node represents a feature in the input examples.
trans-unit.target: The first line defines the input layer (named Data), which has 100 nodes, and each node represents a feature in the input examples.

trans-unit.source: The second line creates the hidden layer.
trans-unit.target: The second line creates the hidden layer.

trans-unit.source: The name H is assigned to the hidden layer, which has 200 nodes.
trans-unit.target: The name H is assigned to the hidden layer, which has 200 nodes.

trans-unit.source: This layer is fully connected to the input layer.
trans-unit.target: This layer is fully connected to the input layer.

trans-unit.source: The third line defines the output layer (named O), and it contains 10 output nodes.
trans-unit.target: The third line defines the output layer (named O), and it contains 10 output nodes.

trans-unit.source: For classification neural networks, there is one output node per class.
trans-unit.target: For classification neural networks, there is one output node per class.

trans-unit.source: The keyword sigmoid indicates that the output function is applied to the output layer.
trans-unit.target: The keyword sigmoid indicates that the output function is applied to the output layer.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to define a slightly more complex neural network, with multiple custom hidden layers.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to define a slightly more complex neural network, with multiple custom hidden layers.

trans-unit.source: This example illustrates several features of the neural networks specification language:
trans-unit.target: This example illustrates several features of the neural networks specification language:

trans-unit.source: The structure has two input layers, Pixels and MetaData.
trans-unit.target: The structure has two input layers, Pixels and MetaData.

trans-unit.source: The Pixels layer is a source layer for two connection bundles, with destination layers, ByRow and ByCol.
trans-unit.target: The Pixels layer is a source layer for two connection bundles, with destination layers, ByRow and ByCol.

trans-unit.source: The layers, Gather and Result, are destination layers in multiple connection bundles.
trans-unit.target: The layers, Gather and Result, are destination layers in multiple connection bundles.

trans-unit.source: The output layer, Result, is a destination layer in two connection bundles; one with the second level hidden (Gather) as a destination layer, and the other with the input layer (MetaData) as a destination layer.
trans-unit.target: The output layer, Result, is a destination layer in two connection bundles; one with the second level hidden (Gather) as a destination layer, and the other with the input layer (MetaData) as a destination layer.

trans-unit.source: The hidden layers, ByRow and ByCol, specify filtered connectivity by using predicate expressions.
trans-unit.target: The hidden layers, ByRow and ByCol, specify filtered connectivity by using predicate expressions.

trans-unit.source: More precisely, the node in ByRow at [x, y] is connected to those nodes in Pixels by having the first index coordinate equal to the node's first coordinate, x.
trans-unit.target: More precisely, the node in ByRow at [x, y] is connected to those nodes in Pixels by having the first index coordinate equal to the node's first coordinate, x.

trans-unit.source: Si
trans-unit.target: Si

trans-unit.source: milarly, the node in ByCol at [x, y] is connected to those nodes in Pixels by having the second index coordinate within one of the node's second coordinate, y.
trans-unit.target: milarly, the node in ByCol at [x, y] is connected to those nodes in Pixels by having the second index coordinate within one of the node's second coordinate, y.

trans-unit.source: The definition of the following network is designed to recognize numbers, and it illustrates some advanced techniques for customizing a neural network.
trans-unit.target: The definition of the following network is designed to recognize numbers, and it illustrates some advanced techniques for customizing a neural network.

trans-unit.source: The structure has a single input layer, Image.
trans-unit.target: The structure has a single input layer, Image.

trans-unit.source: The keyword convolve indicates that Conv1 and Conv2 are convolutional layers.
trans-unit.target: The keyword convolve indicates that Conv1 and Conv2 are convolutional layers.

trans-unit.source: Each of these layer declarations is followed by a list of the convolution attributes.
trans-unit.target: Each of these layer declarations is followed by a list of the convolution attributes.

trans-unit.source: The net has a third hidden layer, Hid3, which is fully connected to the second hidden layer, Conv2.
trans-unit.target: The net has a third hidden layer, Hid3, which is fully connected to the second hidden layer, Conv2.

trans-unit.source: The output layer, Digit, is connected only to the third hidden layer, Hid3.
trans-unit.target: The output layer, Digit, is connected only to the third hidden layer, Hid3.

trans-unit.source: The keyword all indicates that the output layer is fully connected to Hid3.
trans-unit.target: The keyword all indicates that the output layer is fully connected to Hid3.

trans-unit.source: The arity of the convolution is three (the length of the tuples InputShape, KernelShape, Stride, and Sharing).
trans-unit.target: The arity of the convolution is three (the length of the tuples InputShape, KernelShape, Stride, and Sharing).

trans-unit.source: The number of weights per kernel is _1 + KernelShape\[0] * KernelShape\[1] * KernelShape\[2] = 1 + 1 * 5 * 5 = 26.
trans-unit.target: The number of weights per kernel is _1 + KernelShape\[0] * KernelShape\[1] * KernelShape\[2] = 1 + 1 * 5 * 5 = 26.

trans-unit.source: You can calculate the nodes in each hidden layer as follows:
trans-unit.target: You can calculate the nodes in each hidden layer as follows:

trans-unit.source: NodeCount\[0] = (5 - 1) / 1 + 1 = 5.
trans-unit.target: NodeCount\[0] = (5 - 1) / 1 + 1 = 5.

trans-unit.source: NodeCount\[1] = (13 - 5) / 2 + 1 = 5.
trans-unit.target: NodeCount\[1] = (13 - 5) / 2 + 1 = 5.

trans-unit.source: NodeCount\[2] = (13 - 5) / 2 + 1 = 5.
trans-unit.target: NodeCount\[2] = (13 - 5) / 2 + 1 = 5.

trans-unit.source: The total number of nodes can be calculated by using the declared dimensionality of the layer, [50, 5, 5], as follows: _MapCount * NodeCount\[0] * NodeCount\[1] * NodeCount\[2] = 10 * 5 * 5 * 5_
trans-unit.target: The total number of nodes can be calculated by using the declared dimensionality of the layer, [50, 5, 5], as follows: _MapCount * NodeCount\[0] * NodeCount\[1] * NodeCount\[2] = 10 * 5 * 5 * 5_

trans-unit.source: Because Sharing[d] is False only for d == 0, the number of kernels is _MapCount * NodeCount\[0] = 10 * 5 = 50_.
trans-unit.target: Because Sharing[d] is False only for d == 0, the number of kernels is _MapCount * NodeCount\[0] = 10 * 5 = 50_.
